SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 13 of the passage.
:box:“The prima ballerina became jealous and 𝗕𝗔𝗡𝗜𝗦𝗛𝗘𝗗 the new girl to dance only on Thursdays, when people were too busy for ballet.”
What does the word 𝗕𝗔𝗡𝗜𝗦𝗛𝗘𝗗 mean as it is used in this sentence?

A.Choice: removed

B.Choice: invited

C.Choice: suggested

D.Choice: required

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which word 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes how Gisela's family feels about her dream of becoming a great ballerina?

A.Choice: concerned

B.Choice: surprised

C.Choice: supportive

D.Choice: curious

Content: Select 𝗧𝗪𝗢 details from the passage that 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 support the correct answer to Part A.

A.Choice: “She was thinking about this when her mother walked in. 'Ready for the big day?'” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “'You've practiced a lot. You dance beautifully. Let's get you dressed.'” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “They'd never missed a ballet performance.” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “Abuela didn't need any begging.” (paragraph 12)

E.Choice: “As she twirled during her solo, Gisela could hear Mami and Abuela cheering.” (paragraph 17)

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which 𝗧𝗛𝗥𝗘𝗘 details from the passage show that Gisela is worried about how she compares to other ballerinas?

A.Choice: “Then her eye began to twitch, the way it always did when she got jittery.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “But when she looked in the mirror, she found her body too round, too short, too different from the pencil- thin ballerinas she had seen at the Miami City Ballet.” (paragraph 3)

C.Choice: “'Ay, Mami, I'm nervous,' she confessed.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “Gisela couldn't bring herself to tell Mami what really troubled her heart.” (paragraph 7)

E.Choice: “Almost perfect, she thought when she looked in the mirror.” (paragraph 7)

F.Choice: “During the drive to the recital, Gisela was quiet.” (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Which statement describes one way that Gisela and the new girl in Abuela's story are alike?

A.Choice: They are both famous dancers.

B.Choice: They both dance with soul.

C.Choice: They both feel nervous before performing.

D.Choice: They are both envied by other dancers.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Gisela feels confident once she begins to dance because

A.Choice: she knows her parents are in the audience.

B.Choice: she practiced the dance many times.

C.Choice: Abuela's story keeps running through her mind.

D.Choice: the other dancers calm her down.

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Based on the passage, the new dancer in Abuela's story

A.Choice: feels as worried as Gisela about how she looked.

B.Choice: prefers to dance for smaller crowds on Thursdays.

C.Choice: wants to become as famous as the prima ballerina.

D.Choice: is much more popular than the prima ballerina.

Content: Which sentence from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the correct answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'She was the only star— until one day there came a new dancer.'” (paragraph 12)

B.Choice: “'There was something different about the new girl.'” (paragraph 12)

C.Choice: “'But people came even on Thursdays, even when it was raining.'” (paragraph 13)

D.Choice: “'The girl had a beautiful soul and everyone could see that.'” (paragraph 13)

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
What is one theme of the passage?

A.Choice: Pay attention to others.

B.Choice: Grandparents have wisdom to share.

C.Choice: Meeting other people's expectations is hard.

D.Choice: Learn to love who you are.

Content: Select 𝗧𝗪𝗢 details  that 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 support the correct answer to Part A.

A.Choice: “Gisela took her place among the other ballerinas.” (paragraph 15)

B.Choice: “Gisela knew her routine.” (paragraph 17)

C.Choice: “Gisela danced with all her soul.” (paragraph 18)

D.Choice: “When the curtain came down, she could hear Papi's voice above the others... ” (paragraph 19)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: In paragraph 1, the author states, “And he carries these two- tone fluff- balls between their sleeping pens and their public enclosure.” This means that

A.Choice: the pandas move around a lot.

B.Choice: the pandas need help walking.

C.Choice: the pandas sleep more when they are outside.

D.Choice: the pandas sleep and play in different places.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: In paragraph 2, Huang uses the word 𝗝𝗘𝗔𝗟𝗢𝗨𝗦 to show that people

A.Choice: wish they had his job.

B.Choice: think he does a good job.

C.Choice: are thankful that he does his job.

D.Choice: would be upset if he left his job.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 3.
:box:“I'm a full- time daddy for these fluffy baby pandas,” says Huang.
Which 𝗧𝗪𝗢 details 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 support Huang's statement?

A.Choice: “He might have the best job in the world.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “The 24- year- old is a panda photographer and zookeeper.” (paragraph 1)

C.Choice: “He prepares their meals of bamboo and milk formula.” (paragraph 1)

D.Choice: “'I get to hug them all the time.'” (paragraph 2)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 4 of the passage.
:box:They are the only twin pandas born from a wild father and 𝗖𝗔𝗣𝗧𝗜𝗩𝗘 mother.
In this sentence, pandas that are 𝗖𝗔𝗣𝗧𝗜𝗩𝗘 are

A.Choice: calm near humans.

B.Choice: dangerous to humans.

C.Choice: cared for by humans.

D.Choice: loving toward humans.

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Based on information in the passage, what was the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 solution to saving the pandas?

A.Choice: providing specialized training to zookeepers who work with pandas

B.Choice: finding new environments where pandas can safely live

C.Choice: widening the genetic pool by developing breeding programs

D.Choice: sending pandas across the world to create greater awareness

Content: Which detail 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Huang spends each day caring for 18 panda cubs at the Giant Panda Protection and Research Center, in China.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “This helps widen the animal's genetic pool, which means a better chance at survival.” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “Pandas must eat 30 to 85 pounds of bamboo every day.” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “Today, more than 50 pandas live in 18 countries.” (paragraph 8)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 6 of the passage.
:box:Giant pandas are 𝗡𝗔𝗧𝗜𝗩𝗘 to China.
In this sentence, 𝗡𝗔𝗧𝗜𝗩𝗘 means that pandas

A.Choice: live in China.

B.Choice: travel to China.

C.Choice: are symbols of China.

D.Choice: can only survive in China.

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: Which structure does the author use to organize paragraphs 6 through 8 of the passage?

A.Choice: chronology

B.Choice: cause/effect

C.Choice: problem/solution

D.Choice: comparison

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
In paragraph 10, the author writes, “Any offspring remain China's property.” This means that

A.Choice: pandas can stay in the country where they are sent.

B.Choice: baby pandas that are born in other countries belong to China.

C.Choice: pandas are not allowed to leave China.

D.Choice: China does not own any of the pandas born in other countries.

Content: Which detail from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “This is called 'panda diplomacy.'” (paragraph 8)

B.Choice: “Today, more than 50 pandas live in 18 countries.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “It charges about $1 million per year for the service.” (paragraph 10)

D.Choice: “But if a deal goes sour, China may take the pandas back.” (paragraph 10)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Interpret information presented visually, orally, or quantitatively (e.g., in charts, graphs, diagrams, time lines, Web pages) and explain how the information contributes to an understanding of the text in which it appears.
Content: What does the second picture in the passage help the reader understand?

A.Choice: Humans are important to pandas' survival.

B.Choice: Humans help build new habitats for pandas.

C.Choice: Pandas are dangerous to humans.

D.Choice: Pandas are bred in other countries.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Read the sentence from line 8 of the poem.
:box:They 𝗣𝗘𝗥𝗖𝗛 and have a quiet stare at children playing here and there.
The word 𝗣𝗘𝗥𝗖𝗛 means that Nita and Navi are

A.Choice: playing on the swings.

B.Choice: hanging upside down.

C.Choice: walking around in silence.

D.Choice: sitting above the playground.

Content: Which evidence from the poem 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Her feet, they poke in the sky.” (line 2)

B.Choice: “Her feet swim lightly in the air.” (line 4)

C.Choice: “He wants to help her understand.” (line 6)

D.Choice: “From up here they can see a lot.” (line 7)

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
In the poem, why does Nita hang upside down and hide behind her hair?

A.Choice: She enjoys playing at the playground by herself.

B.Choice: She feels like she is different from others.

C.Choice: She likes the way it makes her hair feel.

D.Choice: She wants everyone to see her hanging upside down.

Content: Which detail from the poem 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “... her long hair tickling at the ground.” (line 1)

B.Choice: “Her feet, they poke in the sky.” (line 2)

C.Choice: “He says, 'I've seen you here before.'” (line 3)

D.Choice: “'I'm not the same. I don't fit in.'” (line 5)

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text; summarize the text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which sentence 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 states one theme in the poem?

A.Choice: Differences are useful.

B.Choice: Differences can be frightening.

C.Choice: Differences can be healthy.

D.Choice: Differences should be ignored.

Content: Which detail from the poem 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 shows this theme?

A.Choice: “'You're upside down again! What for?'” (line 3)

B.Choice: “She tries to hide behind her hair.” (line 4)

C.Choice: “Those kids are not the same at all.” (line 9)

D.Choice: “To play, we can't all be the same.” (line 17)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including those that allude to significant characters found in mythology (e.g., Herculean).
Content: What does the word 𝗤𝗨𝗔𝗥𝗥𝗘𝗟 in line 9 of the play help the reader understand about the relationship between the Mammals, Fish, and Birds?

A.Choice: They are getting to know each other.

B.Choice: They are having a disagreement.

C.Choice: They are the best of friends.

D.Choice: They are talking with one another.

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which quotation from the play Why the Platypus is Special 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the idea that the Platypus makes a good decision?

A.Choice: “As promised, Platypus carefully considered which group to join.” (line 24)

B.Choice: “Finally, in the cool evening, Platypus came outside.” (line 28)

C.Choice: “Now, by chance, a hunter was listening to Platypus talking to the animals that evening.” (line 37)

D.Choice: “I will go back to my people and tell them about the extraordinary wisdom of the Platypus.” (line 38)

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 4 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Which definition 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 matches the use of the word 𝗡𝗘𝗥𝗩𝗘 as it is used in line 31 of the play?

A.Choice: power of endurance or control

B.Choice: fearless boldness

C.Choice: behavior marked by a rude or disrespectful tone

D.Choice: a sore or sensitive point

SubTopics: Describe in depth a character, setting, or event in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., a character's thoughts, words, or actions).
Content: Which sentence from the play Why the Platypus is Special 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the idea that Platypus appreciates his friends because of their differences?

A.Choice: “I have parts of EACH of you, and parts of ALL of you. And that is exactly the way I wish to stay.” (line 29)

B.Choice: “So, while I thank you for asking, I choose not to join any of you.” (line 29)

C.Choice: “What kind of an answer is that?” (line 32)

D.Choice: “Each of us is special.” (line 33)

SubTopics: Compare and contrast the treatment of similar themes and topics (e.g., opposition of good and evil) and patterns of events (e.g., the quest) in stories, myths, and traditional literature from different cultures.
Content: Read the sentences Platypus repeats throughout Why the Platypus is Special.
:box:I will carefully consider your request. Thank you for asking me to be a part of your family.
These words show that Platypus is similar to Navi in the poem “Why is Nita Upside Down?” because

A.Choice: they both take their time to answer their friends.

B.Choice: they both are kind to their friends.

C.Choice: they both have difficulty understanding their friends.

D.Choice: they both feel frustrated with their friends.

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: “Why is Nita Upside Down?” and Why the Platypus is Special are both about being different. Write an essay that explains how the idea of being different is shown in both passages. Include specific details from 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 the poem and the play to support your answer.

SubTopics: Explain events, procedures, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text, including what happened and why, based on specific information in the text.
Content: What is the only way for a pilot to steer a hot air balloon?

A.Choice: By controlling how much weight is in the balloon

B.Choice: By opening the flap to make the balloon move in circles

C.Choice: By looking for clear areas without trees or telephone wires

D.Choice: By moving the balloon up or down to catch different winds

SubTopics: Refer to details and examples in a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: According to the passage, why do people feel like they are not moving when riding in a hot air balloon?

A.Choice: The balloon floats very high up in the air.

B.Choice: The balloon moves at the same speed as the wind.

C.Choice: The balloon becomes part of the morning sky.

D.Choice: The balloon is lifted up by very hot air.

SubTopics: Describe the overall structure (e.g., chronology, comparison, cause/effect, problem/solution) of events, ideas, concepts, or information in a text or part of a text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
How does the author organize the information in paragraphs 1 and 2?

A.Choice: Order of events

B.Choice: Compare and contrast

C.Choice: Problem then solution

D.Choice: Main idea supported by details

Content: Which reason 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to part A?

A.Choice: The Moon landing is shown to be different from other space trips.

B.Choice: The text explains how humans solved the problem of landing on the Moon.

C.Choice: Moments from the Moon landing are described in sequence.

D.Choice: Evidence is given to prove that people landed on the Moon.

SubTopics: Determine the main idea of a text and explain how it is supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: According to the passage, what 𝗧𝗛𝗥𝗘𝗘 things did the astronauts do on the surface of the Moon?

A.Choice: They took photographs.

B.Choice: They repaired the lunar module.

C.Choice: They collected objects to bring back to Earth.

D.Choice: They conducted some experiments.

E.Choice: They drew pictures of the Moon.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words or phrases in a text relevant to a grade 4 topic or subject area.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
What is the meaning of 𝗢𝗣𝗘𝗥𝗔𝗧𝗘 as it is used in paragraph 4 of the passage “Apollo 11: The Eagle Has Landed”?

A.Choice: handle

B.Choice: improve

C.Choice: deliver

D.Choice: examine

Content: Which detail from paragraph 4 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “... training for this mission.”

B.Choice: “... if something went wrong.”

C.Choice: “... his ship had spun wildly.”

D.Choice: “... he managed to fix the problem.”

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Integrate information from two texts on the same topic in order to write or speak about the subject knowledgeably.
Content: Select 𝗧𝗛𝗥𝗘𝗘 things that piloting a hot air balloon and piloting a spaceship have in common.

A.Choice: Zero gravity makes you feel like you are floating.

B.Choice: Using the wind is important for steering.

C.Choice: Training, practice, and experience are important.

D.Choice: You get to look at Earth in a totally different way.

E.Choice: Landing in a clear, safe area is difficult.

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: The authors of the two passages use specific details to help the readers understand what it feels like to fly in either a hot air balloon or a spaceship. Write a narrative about an experience related to flying. Your story can be about a hot air balloon ride, a trip in space, or something else, real or imagined. Use information from the passages to help develop the ideas in your narrative.
